speaker: Neil
text: Welcome to 6 Minute English. In this programme we bring you an expressive topic and six items of vocabulary. I’m Neil…

speaker: Tim
text: And I’m Tim. So, we had an argument just before we started the show…

speaker: Neil
text: We did, Tim. But no hard feelings?

speaker: No hard feelings
text: None. No hard feelings is something you say to somebody you have argued with to say you’d still like to be friends. We often fall out over silly things…

speaker: Neil
text: … Like who’s going to introduce the show…

speaker: Tim
text: … Or who’s going to choose the quiz question.

speaker: To fall out with somebody
text: But we understand each other. That’s the important thing, isn't it? To fall out with somebody by the way, is another way of saying to argue or disagree with them. Do you know that you wave your arms around a lot when you’re arguing, Tim?

speaker: Tim
text: No, I didn’t know I did that.

speaker: Neil
text: That isn’t very British.

speaker: gestures
text: I know. Using gestures – or movements you make with your hands or your head to express what you are thinking of feeling – is common in some countries but not in others. Then there are some movements – like shaking your head – which mostly means ‘no’ but in some countries can mean the opposite.

speaker: Neil
text: That’s right. In which country does shaking your head mean ‘yes’, Tim? Is it…

speaker: Neil
text: a) Greece,

speaker: Neil
text: b) Japan or

speaker: Neil
text: c) Bulgaria?

speaker: Tim
text: No idea – I’ll guess Greece. I do know that in India people shake their heads to mean lots of different things.

speaker: Neil
text: There are plenty of gestures you need to be careful with when you’re meeting and greeting people from a culture that’s different to your own – to avoid offending people – or making an awkward faux pas…

speaker: faux pas
text: If you make a faux pas it means you say or do something embarrassing in a social situation. For example, our every day use of the thumbs-up signal might offend people from the Middle East.

speaker: to offend
text: And to offend means to make somebody angry or upset.

speaker: Tim
text: Let’s hear now from Business Professor Erin Meyer talking about how easy it is to misunderstand why people behave the way they do in everyday situations when we don’t belong to the same culture.

speaker: Erin Meyer, Business Professor in Dubai
text: A while ago I was in Dubai and one of my students, my Emirati students, was driving me home after a session and the car stopped at a light and she rolled down the window, and she started shouting at someone outside of the window. This guy was crossing the street with a big box of cloth. And he started shouting back, and she opened up the door, and they started gesticulating and shouting at one another. And I thought, wow, they’re having a huge fight, I thought maybe he was going to hit her. And she got back in the car, and I said, well, what were you fighting about? And she said, ‘Oh no, no, we weren’t fighting, he was giving me directions to your hotel.’ And I thought that was a great example of how someone from another culture may misperceive or misunderstand something as a fight when in fact they were just being emotionally expressive.

speaker: Gesticulating
text: Gesticulating – what does that mean?

speaker: Tim
text: It means what I was doing earlier! – Waving your arms around to express what you’re feeling.

speaker: Neil
text: Erin Meyer was worried because her student and the man on the street were shouting and gesticulating at each other. She thought they were having a fight when in fact they were just being emotionally expressive.

speaker: expressive
text: And expressive means showing what you think or feel.

speaker: Neil
text: You were nodding in agreement, there, Tim. Which reminds me of our quiz question. In which country does shaking your head mean ‘yes’? Is it… a) Greece, b) Japan or c) Bulgaria?

speaker: Tim
text: I said Greece…

speaker: Neil
text: And that’s the wrong answer, I’m afraid. The right answer is Bulgaria. In some Southeastern European areas such as Bulgaria and southern Albania, shaking your head is used to indicate "yes". In those regions, nodding in fact means "no" as well.

speaker: Tim
text: I hope I remember that the next time I meet somebody from Southeastern Europe.OK, shall we look back at the words we learned today?

speaker: Neil
text: ‘No hard feelings’ is something you say to somebody you have argued with or beaten in a game or contest to say you’d still like to be friends.

speaker: Tim
text: For example, “I always get the quiz questions right – unlike you Neil. But no hard feelings, OK?”

speaker: Neil
text: That’s not a very realistic example, Tim… But I’ll let it go. Number two – ‘to fall out with somebody’ means to argue or disagree with them.

speaker: Tim
text: “I fell out with my best friend at school. We didn’t talk to each other for a whole week!”

speaker: Neil
text: That must’ve been a serious disagreement, Tim! What were you arguing about?

speaker: Tim
text: I can’t remember. It was a long time ago. Number three – a ‘gesture’ is a movement you make with your hands or head to express what you are thinking or feeling.

speaker: Neil
text: “She opened her arms wide in a gesture of welcome.”

speaker: Tim
text: Or the verb – “I gestured to Neil that we only had one minute left to finish the show!”

speaker: Neil
text: Is that true, Tim? You’re nodding your head – but we should also quickly mention ‘gesticulate’ which means to make gestures with your hands or arms!

speaker: Tim
text: A ‘faux pas’ is saying or doing something embarrassing in a social situation. For example, “I committed a serious faux pas at a party last night – that I’m too embarrassed to tell you about!”

speaker: Neil
text: Oh dear, Tim. I hope you didn’t offend too many people – ‘offend’ is our next word – and it means to make somebody angry or upset.

speaker: Tim
text: Well, you’ve given us a good example already, Neil, so let’s move on to the final word – ‘expressive’ – which means showing what you think or feel.

speaker: Neil
text: “Tim has a very expressive face.”

speaker: Tim
text: Thanks! Another quick example – “I waved my hand expressively to signal to Neil that it was time to finish the show.”

speaker: Neil
text: Taking my cue from Tim, that’s all for today. But please remember to check out our Instagram, Twitter, Facebook and YouTube pages.

speaker: Tim
text: Bye-bye!

speaker: Neil
text: Goodbye!
